contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Magazine | title = King Magazine | image_file = Rosa Acosta on the cover of King.jpg | image_size = 200px | image_caption = [[Rosa Acosta]] on the cover of the Winter 2010 issue of King | editor = | frequency = Quarterly | circulation = | category = [[African American]], [[Men's magazine]] | company = [[Harris Publications]] | firstdate = | lastdate = March 2009 | country = {{Flag|United States}} | language = | website = [http://www.king-mag.com/ http://www.king-mag.com/] | issn = }} '''''King''''' is a monthly [[men's magazine]] geared toward [[African American]] and [[urban area|urban]] audiences. It features articles about [[Hip hop music|hip-hop]] and [[R&B]] as well as sports and fashion. The magazine is published by [[Harris Publications]] and was a spinoff from ''[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]''.<ref name="nytimes-20040831">{{cite news |first=Lola |last=Ogunnaike |title=New Magazines for Black Men Proudly Redefine the Pinup |url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9404E5DD1731F932A0575BC0A9629C8B63 |work=The New York Times |publisher= |date=August 31, 2004 |accessdate=22 December 2008 }}</ref> It ceased publication on March 31, 2009, citing failing ad sales as a result of the poor economy and plans to release monthly installments soon.<ref>[http://www.sohh.com/2009/03/breaking_king_magazine_fo.html News: BREAKING: King Magazine Folds, Falling Ad Market To Blame]</ref> It resumed publication, this time as a quarterly magazine, in late 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/online/?p=67038 |title=King Magazine's EIC Revealed |publisher=[[XXL (magazine)|XXLmag.com]] |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=January 8, 2010 }}</ref> ''King'' magazine is mainly characterized by its lavish [[photoshoots]], which usually feature scantily-clad women, often complete with an interview from the featured model. The subjects of these shoots range from professional models such as [[Melyssa Ford]] and [[Toccara]] to well-known musicians and actresses, including [[Trina]], [[Keyshia Cole]] and [[Elise Neal]]. It also features interviews with rappers. The magazine almost exclusively uses pictures from its photoshoots as the cover of the magazine. The magazine is sometimes called "The black ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]''". The Lycos 50 Daily Report noted the magazine received more online searches than ''Newsweek'' or ''Reader's Digest''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://50.lycos.com/090803.asp |title=Hot Read: King Magazine |accessdate=22 December 2008|work=Lycos 50 |publisher=Lycos |date=8 September 2003}}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Westhoff |title=End Run |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2007-05-22/news/end-run/ |work=The Village Voice |publisher= |date=May 22, 2007 |accessdate=January 25, 2009 }} == External links == *[http://www.king-mag.com/ Official site] *[http://www.myspace.com/kingmagazine ''King'''s Myspace Page] [[Category:American men's magazines]] [[Category:Harris Publications titles]] [[Category:African-American magazines]] [[Category:Defunct magazines of the United States]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 2009]] {{African American press}} {{AfricanAmerican-stub}} {{mens-mag-stub}} Comm 200 is the best class at Loyola University. The King Magazine is a prime example of media and how different outlets can reach different audiences.
